headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Disqualification Hearing For DA Fani Willis Might Stall Investigation Of Trump; Nathan Wade, Georgia Prosecutor, Asked Over His Relationship With Fani Willis. Aired 10:30-11a ET

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, DEFENSE ATTORNEY FOR MIKE ROMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: So, 19 -- probably '90 or '91.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And have you been Friends since 19 90or '91?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. When was the last time you spoke with Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: March of 20 -- March of 2022.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. From 1991-ish till 2022, were you what you would consider good friends with Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And did you all share personal information regularly? YEARTIE

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And did you even come and work with her at the DA's office?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And when she needed a place to stay, did you let her stay at your apartment? Your --

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: -- it was a condo, right?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Condo, yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Do you remember approximately when she moved into your condo?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: It was April of 2021.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Great. And you know that Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade met at a conference in October of 2019.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to that, Your Honor, without a foundation for how this witness would know that. If Ms. Merchant can establish she had personal information of that, then certainly that's something the witness can testify to. But if it's -- she heard it from --

utterances.speaker: SCOTT MCAFEE, JUDGE, SUPERIOR COURT OF FULTON COUNTY
utterances.sentences: I understand, Ms. Cross. All right. Ms. Merchant, if you could lay the foundation.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Do you have information that Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade met in October of 2019?ANNA GREEN CROSS, ATTORNEY FOR FULTON COUNTY DA'S OFFICE:  I'm going to renew my objection, Your Honor. Information does not source to personal information. If the question can be rephrased, then that may address my concern.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, Judge, I -- let me -- I just want to make sure that I understand. So, they have objected to me calling Willis and Wade --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: It's just a matter of foundation. If you can just rephrase.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Do you have knowledge of when Willis and Wade met?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object again. Personal knowledge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Overruled.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Do you have personal knowledge of when Willis and Wade met?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: She told me that they met conference. I don't know what conference.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to renew my objection, Your Honor. Clearly, this is not firsthand information from this witness. It's hearsay that was --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Which is that -- she told me.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's statement against interest, Judge. If Ms. Willis --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Just pause.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK. Ms. Cross.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: The representation of the witness, the testimony of the witness was that Ms. Willis, District Attorney Willis had a conversation with her. There is no statement against interest. District Attorney Willis is not a party opponent in this case. The information that the witness has testified to came from Ms. Willis and there's -- we have a hearsay objection to that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Why wouldn't she be considered a party opponent in this context?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: She is a representative of the state, Your Honor. This isn't private litigation or civil litigation. Obviously, the question (ph) -- this is -- Ms. Willis is not on trial. Ms. Willis has not -- is not a party to the litigation outside her obligation to pursue criminal charges for the state.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I guess it's evolved into a hearsay objection.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Judge. And we plan on calling Ms. Willis to the stand. She's under subpoena. So, hearsay will be cured if there is a hearsay objection as so far as that issue. But we do still think that it's a statement against interest. Ms. Willis has filed a document that states that they met at this municipal court conference. So --

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm -- Your Honor, I think maybe I can streamline a little bit. State will stipulate that District Attorney Willis and Mr. Wade met in October 2019 at the judicial conference that we've been talking about. There's no reason to get it secondhand from this witness. Well, that's true.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Do you accept the stipulation, Ms. Merchant?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Am I permitted then to ask questions about that since it's now not hearsay?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: If it's just to a stipulation, if it's just to that basic fact, I don't think we need a question if there's a follow-up.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Ms. Yeartie, you have personal knowledge that Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade began their romantic relationship soon after this time that they met at the municipal court?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to that question that certainly is a leading question. No foundation has been laid for how this witness would have personal knowledge of that. Until that's happened, the state objects.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I think you can do a yes or no and then follow-up with how she knows it.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.Do you know if Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade started dating in October of 2019?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: I don't know if it was October of 2019.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Could it possibly be November of 2019?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Could possibly.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And when we spoke, you said it was shortly after the municipal court conference, though, correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So, you know that their relationship, their personal relationship began shortly after this municipal court conference?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And when I say personal, romantic, is that -- is -- I just want to make sure we don't get in an argument over what personal and romantic is later. When I ask you personal, do you take that to mean romantic?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you were essentially her best friend during this time, right?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Not best friend. Good friend.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Good friend, OK. Close friend. And so, would you frequently socialize with her?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you saw her at work every day?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, you had a chance to see them interact together on a personal level?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And so, from everything that you saw, heard, witnessed, it's your understanding that they were in a romantic relationship beginning in 2019.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And when you left the D.A. -- oh, I'm sorry. Let me ask you, you said that Ms. Willis came to live with you in April of 2021 -- I'm sorry. April 1st 2020 or 2021?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: She didn't live -- I never lived with her.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. I'm sorry. She took over your lease in April 1m, 2020, correct?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: 20 -- OK. I'm -- I had it both ways, so I'm glad you clarified. So, when she took over your lease in April 1, 2021, it's your understanding she moved out of the house that she was sharing with her father and started staying at the condo?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And is it your understanding that that's because she needed to have her own space?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Away from her father?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No, I resigned.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You resigned. OK.Just one moment, Judge. Can you tell us why you resigned to the D.A.'s office?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: The number of things that was happening.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: A number of things were happening, is that what you said, ma'am?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. What was happening that you that caused you to resign?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: It was a spiral of things. So, I guess the last draw is I was put in a department that I knew had no knowledge about, something happened, and I didn't like it. They didn't like it. And that was it.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Did you have any falling outs with Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Well, we never spoke after that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You never spoke after that, OK. And so, you're -- you know, without going into all the painstaking details, there is no doubt in your mind that from 2019 until 2022, Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade were in a romantic relationship?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: What's the question?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You have no doubt that their romantic relationship was in effect from 2019 until the last time you spoke with her?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No doubt.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And that's based on your personal observations and observe -- and, you know, speaking with them and seeing them together and things like that?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. No other questions. Thank you. The other folks may after I have some questions for you, Ms. Yeartie.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Sadow (ph).SADOW (PH):  Do you want me to go to the --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: If it's more than a couple questions, then sure. But if not --SADOW (PH):  It's only a couple of questions. I think --

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  Did Ms. Willis tell call you on more than one occasion that she was engaged in a romantic relationship with Mr. Wade prior to you leaving the district attorney's office.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Did she tell me or did I observe?SADOW (PH):  What? I'm saying -- right now, you could (ph) tell me.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  Did she tell you that in the year of 2020?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  In the year of 2021?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  Are you certain that Ms. Wade told you -- I'm sorry, Ms. Willis told you about I think the romantic relationship with Mr. Wade prior to November 1st of 2021.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  Now, did you also have observations of Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis together prior to November 1st of 2021?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  And are those observations, were those in a social setting?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  And did you observe them do things that are -- is it common among people having a romantic relationship?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.SADOW (PH):  Such as? Can you give us an example?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Hugging, kissing, those affection.SADOW (PH):  All before November 1st of 2021, correct? YEARTIE:  Yes. SADOW (PH):  That's all I have.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Docks (ph)?DOCKS (PH):  Ma'am, did I understand you decided that, you know, the period of time when you and Ms. Willis lived together?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.DOCKS (PH):  No further questions.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Mr. Durham?

utterances.speaker: JIM DURHAM
utterances.sentences: Nothing from me, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. McDougall (ph)?MCDOUGALL (PH):  Nothing, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Rice (ph)?RICE (PH):  Good morning, Ms. Yeartie. Are you -- were you aware in 2021 of any trips, social trips that Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade took together?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.RICE (PH):  Are you aware of any social trips that Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade took together in 2022?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.RICE (PH):  And are you aware of them in 2020 or 2021 spending the evening together overnight?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: None.RICE (PH):  No further questions.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Gillen (ph)?GILLEN (PH):  No questions, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. McCullough (ph)?MCCULLOUGH (PH):  No questions.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Cromwell (ph)?CROMWELL (PH):  No questions, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Cross.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I do have some questions. Thank you, Your Honor. Ms. Yeartie, we haven't met before, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You're able to see and hear me OK?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. I want to start with couple of things. Now, I think you've made it clear that you never lived -- and we'll call it the South Fulton address, the South Fulton condo that you were leasing, you never lived at that address with District Attorney Willis, correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And never at any time?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Never.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. You never observed or have any information about District Attorney Wade and -- District Attorney Willis and Nathan Wade living together, correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You don't have any information about that?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No, I don't.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Anybody said that that information was sourced to you that that's incorrect?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: That's incorrect.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Did District Attorney Willis pay rent at that establishment, at that condo while you -- while she lived there and you were living elsewhere?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Who paid the rent?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: She didn't.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Nathan Wade ever pay the rent?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And you never told anyone otherwise? I didn't answer -- I didn't hear your answer there, Ms. Yeartie. Did you ever tell anyone otherwise?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. So, let's talk for a second about time at the district attorney's office. You were disciplined several times in the district attorney's office during your employment there, correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You weren't written up ever for poor performance, Ms. Yeartie?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Once, not several.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: One time you were written up for poor performance. Were you counseled several times about your performance in the district attorney's office that was subpar?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Did the district attorney tell you that your performance was insufficient and that you were going to be fired?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: That never happened?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: The question, Ms. Yeartie, was did the district attorney ever counsel you on your poor performance in the district attorney's office prior -- and inform you that you were going to be fired?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: I don't really know how to answer that.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm looking for the truth.

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: I don't really know how to answer that. I mean, a situation happened that wasn't my fault. And I either was going to resign or be let go. So --

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You understood that that was the situation? You could resign or you could be let go?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Correct. Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You were not welcome to stay?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And the conversation where you informed that you could resign or you could be fired, that conversation was not the first conversation you had with the district attorney about your poor performance in the office, correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Well, it was kind of a spiral, but no.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was. Whatever the situation was --STENO (PH):  Objection --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Excuse me.STENO (PH):  -- by counsel, questions are fine.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Understood, Mr. Steno (ph). Ms. Cross.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Ms. Yeartie, the circumstances of your leaving the district attorney's office ended your friendship with the District Attorney Willis, correct?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You all haven't spoken since?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. I want to talk about the representations that you made here this morning, Ms. Yeartie, about any relationship between District Attorney Willis and Mr. Wade. I wanted you to tell me what was the first time any -- let me ask you this way. You said that District Attorney Willis personally informed you of a romantic relationship. Is that what you testified up to?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: When did that conversation that you purport to have to recall? When did that happen?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: I mean, I don't have a month or a day, but just talking. Just talking in general.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, could I keep this witness under subpoena? But that's all the questions I have right now.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you, Ms. Cross.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I have to recross then -- I mean, redirect. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. On those points only.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, just those points.The state asked you a lot about when you were let go, when you resigned. Did something happen as far as purchasing that you didn't feel comfortable with? Purchasing things through the county for Ms. Willis that caused you to not be comfortable working there anymore?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I didn't tell you how to testify here today, though, right?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And everything you've testified to is from your personal knowledge?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you've told the truth here today?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.Judge, I believe she's only under my subpoena, and I'm fine releasing her from that subpoena. SADOW (PH):  Not yet.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: By show of hands from other counsel, starting with Mr. Sadow (ph).SADOW (PH):  Your honor, I believe the door has been opened now to ask this particular witness about statements that Ms. Willis made to her. She brought it up on cross-examination on a couple of occasions. Did Ms. Willis say this or inform you of that? So, I'd like to now ask her questions directly about what Ms. Willis told her about her romantic relationship.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I think we'll take those one at a time. Question by question, and we can address those to see. I don't know about a complete opening of the door. We'll see where we go.SADOW (PH):  The first time that you spoke to Ms. Willis about her relationship, romantic relationship, with Mr. Wade, do you happen to remember what Ms. Willis said, in essence, not word for word, but in essence what she said?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.SADOW (PH):  Do you remember the first time she told you, in whatever words were used, that there was a romantic relationship?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: No.SADOW (PH):  Is this the kind of conversation that you had with your best friend ongoing over a period of time in which it was common knowledge to you that there was an ongoing relationship between Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: What's the question?SADOW (PH):  I'll ask it again. Is the nature of your then relationship with Ms. Willis such that you were having these ongoing conversations, best friend type conversations about her relationship with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: I don't remember.[10:50:00] SADOW (PH):  We're getting any further in too much detail. Is there any doubt, at all, that Mr. Wade and Ms. Willis had a romantic relationship as was told to you prior to November of 2020?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. She was already asked that question by Ms. Merchant.SADOW (PH):  I just didn't know whether that is --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: She said -- and she said no. No doubt.SADOW (PH):  OK.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Any other defense counsel by show of hands? Seeing none. Last recross from Ms. Cross. Anything else?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Not this time, Your Honor, but we've asked the witness remain under subpoena and subject to recall.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge, she's under my subpoena, and I'm releasing her from my subpoena. So, if they want to subpoena her, they will go under subpoena (ph).

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Cross.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I would prefer that the court keep under subpoena. I think --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: -- given the representation of Ms. Marchant, given how she intends to proceed today, then this witness may need to be recalled.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Understood. In the interest and knowing that we may have to bring witnesses back and forth, I think it's in the interest of effective presentation of the evidence here. Ms. Yeartie, you are still going to remain under the offices of your subpoena. And so, please stay in touch with your attorney. We may need you to rejoin us on Zoom at some point today or tomorrow. Understood?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Don't discuss your testimony with any other potential witnesses, all right?

utterances.speaker: YEARTIE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. You can log off.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And Judge, I'd ask -- just can Mr. Partridge stay on for just one moment?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: For what Reason.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The state have made some allegations that I misrepresented some things to the court. And I just like the opportunity to clear that up, that Mr. Partridge is the one that told me that they lived together for a month. They've called me everything but a liar today. And so, I just think that it's appropriate for everyone to know where that information came from.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Ms. Merchant, I think you've made your position clear. That's -- I don't think we want me to get sidetracked on that. All right. Mr. Merchant, you can call your next witness.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Thank you. You can call Mr. Wade now

utterances.speaker: PARTRIDGE
utterances.sentences: Judge, may I be excused as well, please?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Take care, Mr. Partridge.

utterances.speaker: PARTRIDGE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: So, we have been hearing the testimony of the former assistant or friend of Fani Willis, and a former employee of the district attorney's office. We're hearing a lot of back and forth. She did confirm that she, in fact, had personal knowledge that Nathan Wade and Fani Willis had been in a personal romantic relationship as early as 2019 up until they beat -- they stopped communicating. Following her resignation from the DA's office in 2022. Really important testimony coming in today. Although she was challenged a number of times on the reason she resigned. Trying to establish there's some kind of ax to grind.Nick Valencia is here with me right now. Nick, there were some pretty important moments just now in our testimony. And by the way, she's there under subpoena. No one seems to want to be in this courtroom. Not Mr. Bradley, not Nathan Wade, not Fani Willis, certainly not this witness via Zoom as well. Tell me about the most important moment to you.

utterances.speaker: NICK VALENCIA, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It took a lot of time for us to even get to this point.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: VALENCIA
utterances.sentences: No one seemed to want to testify or talk. It's really important because leading up in today, Ashleigh Merchant, the defense attorney for Mike Roman who brought these allegations to light, she says she proved -- can prove two lies. One, that they cohabitated. That Fani Willis and Nathan Wade lived together. The other, is that she can prove that they are misrepresenting when this relationship began. And it's very important what we just heard here.This is -- was teed up to be a major day, a defining day. And we just heard some very dramatic testimony that seems to contradict specifically what Fani Willis put in a written legal brief responding in court, in writing, submitting this document to court saying that this happened, this relationship, this personal relationship began in 2022. Well, we just heard something that contradicts that.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Right. VALENCIA

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I was surprised though for the questioning. There wasn't more information that was extracted about the nature of why she believed it. She kept being asked, is there any doubt in your mind?

utterances.speaker: VALENCIA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I mean, they should have gone further. What did you see? When did you see? She said she saw affection. Hugging and kissing. But there should have been more testimony about this very notion. Also, the cohabitation part of this, Nick, we know that she was leasing an apartment of some kind, a sublet to Fani Willis through her own testimony.She did not say they cohabitated, was not aware of them actually living together, but she said they -- she was aware of Fani Willis leaving her father's home to then have her own space.

utterances.speaker: VALENCIA
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The intimation, of course, is the why she wanted her own space. That was not brought out in actual testimony.

utterances.speaker: VALENCIA
utterances.sentences: No, and we'll potentially hear more of that from other witnesses because there was the safehouse that was brought up in legal filings where it is alleged that Fani Willis and Nathan Wade cohabitated there by Ashleigh Merchant in her briefs and her filings.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But do we know if that, "Safe house" was actually that?We have Nathan Wade coming into the courtroom, by the way.

utterances.speaker: VALENCIA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Let's watch him. He's coming into the stands. Let's listen in to what he might be saying. Remember, everyone had to be out of the courtroom until they had to testify. Here he is taking the stand about to have the oath.NATHAN WADE, SPECIAL PROSECUTOR IN TRUMP'S GA ELECTION CASE:  My name is Nathan Wade, N-A-T-H-A-N W-A-D-E.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Good morning, Mr. Wade.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Prior to filing this motion to disqualify, you and I were friends, correct?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And in fact, I supported you when you ran for judge in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: You did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I wore your shirts. My kids wore your shirts.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, your personal opinions have no relevance.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: And I mean that in the best way, All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That's completely fine. I will move on.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Let's get to the point.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. No, no, no. I -- totally fine. Thank you.You filed for divorce from your wife on November 2nd 2021?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And in that divorce proceeding, did you file answers, things such as interrogatories?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And so, interrogatories `are where you're responding to things that basically answers that the other side is asking?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I've got your complaint for divorce. I'm just going to mark it for the record as it is defendant's Exhibit 2. The first interrogatories that you answered, those were December 27, 2021, is that right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: There about, yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And in those -- you were asked different things, but those are sworn. You actually swear to those. You verify them, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And so, that verification is where you're swearing under oath that everything in it is true?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And let's see, the -- you were asked if you had any documents were which relate to the purchase of gifts by you to any person other than the defendant with whom you have or had a relationship -- romantic relationship from the date of your marriage, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you responded under oath that you didn't have any documents to that?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You again responded to an interrogatory. You updated those responses on May 30, 2023?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you actually sent those directly to opposing counsel in the divorce?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. I think so.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: But in that one, you answered none against that question, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So, May 30, 2023, you said that you didn't have any documents showing any purchase of anything with someone that you had a romantic relationship with.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I believe the interrogatory was gifts.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Not anything, yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I have it, if you want to take it. I'm going to mark -- OK. So just for the record, I've got your Complaint for divorce marked as number two. I've got the verification and the interrogatories from 2021, I'm going to mark those as three. And then your May 30, 2023, I'm going to mark as four.Judge, may I approach the witness?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: You may.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.That is what I marked as four. This is what I marked as three. OK. Thank you, judge. All right. If you would take a look at what I marked as two, three, and four, I just need you to recognize those.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And are those -- that's your divorce complaint and then your 2021 interrogatory and your 2023 interrogatory, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Are they a fair and accurate representation of what is filed in that case?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'd move to admit those into evidence, Judge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: And this is two, three, and four?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: It's two, three, and four, yes.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Any objection from the state?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The divorce?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: No objection to three and four. And subject to Ms. Merchant's representation that two is a filing of divorce. I just don't -- the divorce complaint, I don't have that in front of me that's subject to that representation, Judge.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. And by show of hands, any objection from other defense counsel? Seeing none, defendants two, three, and four, this should be Roman's -- what we just saw, two, three, and four admitted without objection.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, that interrogatory that you filed in 20 23, that's the one where you said, no. That you didn't have any documents relating to the purchase of gifts that you had a romantic relationship with someone, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Number -- which interrogatory are we talking about?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Number four, 2023.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Which number in the interrogatory?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Number 4?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So, which number interrogatory are you referring to?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: It's defendant's exhibit number four.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I have defendant's exhibit four here.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Which number interrogatory are we referring to?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Oh, which -- like, which number out of the questions?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.
